abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Additional
            Financing for Small Town Water Supply and Sanitation Project
            in Ghana is to increase access to small town water supply
            and sanitation services four regions (Upper East, Upper
            West, Central and Western regions) in four years, by
            providing 500,000 people with water supply facilities, and
            50,000 people with sanitary facilities. The following are
            identified in most cases as the key potential social and
            environmental concerns requiring attention in the four
            project regions to be covered by the additional financing:
            a) public safety issues arising from: (1) poor housekeeping
            by contractors while on site, (2) movement of heavy
            vehicles, and (3) exposure to open trenches; b) removal and
            destruction of properties (crops, trees, structures) to
            locate facilities, and also on the RoWs during pipe laying;
            c) decommissioning of existing old/ abandoned water points
            (wells) for public safety reasons and as potential
            groundwater contamination sources; and d) land acquisition.
            Alternative site selection procedures and redesigning
            options must be followed to ensure that trees, food and cash
            crops as well as structures were avoided. Livelihood issues
            must be identified and addressed including concerns about
            communal facilities and cultural sites. Compensation
            arrangements as described in the Resettlement Policy
            Framework (RPF) must be followed and adequate grievance
            mechanisms instituted to avoid conflicts.
